importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the Paris Climate Agreement was adopted, marking a pivotal shift in global climate policy and setting a target for limiting warming.
A reference point for baseline climate data used in the study (1991–2020 period), establishing the context for measuring warming trends.
The publication date of the study, indicating the most current assessment of climate change impacts based on recent data and models.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The study projects future increases in superhot days from 2021 to 2100 under current emission pathways, emphasizing long-term climate risks.

keyTakeAways: Climate change has led to an increase of 57 superhot days annually by 2100, defined as days warmer than 90% of comparable days between 1991 and 2020.
The Paris Climate Agreement has reduced projected warming from 4°C to 2.6°C, cutting the number of additional superhot days from 114 to 57.
Since 2015, the world has already experienced 11 extra superhot days on average, showing immediate climate impacts.
Small island nations such as Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face disproportionate increases in superhot days, with Panama projected to see 149 more per year.

The top carbon-polluting countries — the U.S., China, and India — are responsible for 42% of global CO₂ emissions but face only 23–30 extra superhot days, highlighting a stark disconnect between emissions and heat exposure.
The study reveals a global injustice in climate impacts, with low-emitting nations suffering more extreme heat, potentially fueling geopolitical tension.

Experts such as Johan Rockstrom and Friederike Otto emphasize that even under current commitments, climate change will still result in massive human suffering, with tens of thousands or millions affected annually.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A research group that conducts climate attribution studies to determine the role of climate change in extreme weather events.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The entity is responsible for conducting the new study that calculates the increase in superhot days due to climate change, providing scientific credibility to the findings.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is central to the study’s narrative, showing how the agreement has reduced projected warming and the number of superhot days by half.

namedEntities.name: Johan Rockstrom

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provided expert commentary emphasizing that even under current climate commitments, the world still faces a disastrous future due to extreme heat.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She contributed to the study and emphasized the human cost of climate change, stating that tens of thousands or millions of people will be affected by hotter days.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new climate study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central finds that even under current commitments to the Paris Climate Agreement, the planet will still experience 57 additional superhot days annually by 2100—nearly two months of extreme heat—compared to pre-2015 projections. While the worst-case scenario of 114 extra days has been reduced by half, the world has already seen 11 more such days since 2015. The study reveals a profound climate injustice: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa are projected to face massive spikes in dangerous heat, with Panama seeing 149 extra days per year, while top emitters such as the U.S., China, and India face only 23–30 extra days despite being responsible for 42% of global CO₂ emissions. Experts like Johan Rockstrom and Friederike Otto warn of severe human suffering and long-term societal risks, including geopolitical instability, due to this growing inequality in climate impacts.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
